rename.from: Refactor time series classifiers into regressors
rename.to: Time series regression: refactoring time series classifiers

issue.title: Roadmap

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
## Overview
| Project | Coordinators |
|---|---|
| [Documentation](#Documentation) | @lynnssi, @mloning, @fkiraly | 
| [Time Series Classification](#Time-Series-Classification) | @TonyBagnall, @mloning |
| [Time Series Regression](#Time-Series-Regression) | @TonyBagnall, @mloning |
| [Time Series Clustering](#Time-Series-Clustering) | @TonyBagnall, @fkiraly, @mloning |
| [Forecasting](#Forecasting) | @mloning, @fkiraly |
| [Supervised/Panel Forecasting](#Supervised/Panel-Forecasting) | @mloning, @fkiraly |
| [Time Series Annotation](#Time-Series-Annotation) | @mloning, @fkiraly |
| [Data container](#Data-Container) | @prockenschaub, @mloning, @fkiraly |
| [Development operations](#Development-operations) | @mloning |

## Documentation
| Project | Links | Description | 
|---|---|---|
| User guide | #377 | Develop user guide | 
| Website | | Improve website | 
| Extension guidelines | | Write guidelines for extending sktime | 
| Contributing guide | | Improve guide for contributing to sktime | 
| Reviewer guide | | Add a reviewer guide to our contributing guide, see e.g. this [blog post](https://rgommers.github.io/2019/06/the-cost-of-an-open-source-contribution/), [Turing Way chapter](https://the-turing-way.netlify.app/reproducible-research/reviewing.html), [Software Construction on MIT OpenCourseWare](https://ocw.mit.edu/ans7870/6/6.005/s16/classes/04-code-review/index.html), [eScienceCentre guide](https://guide.esciencecenter.nl/#/best_practices/code_review) | 
| Glossary | #363 | Add glossary of common terms | 
| Docstrings | | Improve docstrings |
| Blog posts | | Write blog posts |

## Time Series Classification
| Project | Links | Description | 
|---|---|---|
| Multivariate data | | Extend algorithms to handle multivariate data | 
| Parallelization | #381 | Parallelize algorithms using joblib or numba | @mloning |
| Unequal length data | #230 | Extend algorithms to handle unequal length data |
| New algorithms | #259 | Add new algorithms |
| Data simulators | #353 | Add data simulators for unit testing and algorithm explanation/interpretability | 

## Time Series Regression
| Project | Links | Description |
|---|---|---|
| Refactor time series classifiers | #212 | Refactor time series classifiers into time series regressor | 


## Time Series Clustering
| Project | Links | Description |
|---|---|---|
| 2nd degree transformer framework | #52, #105 | Design and implement 2nd degree transformer framework | 
| New algorithms | | Add new clustering algorithms based on scikit-learn's implementation and sktime's time series distances | 
| New distances | | Add new time series distances |

## Forecasting 
| Project | Links | Description | 
|---|---|---|
| Multivariate data | | Extend algorithms to handle multivariate/exogenous data, add new composition tools for multivariate time series data | 
| New algorithms | #220 | Add new algorithms | 
| Prediction intervals | | Extend algorithms to compute prediction intervals |
| Fitted parameter interface | | Extend algorithms to support fitted parameter interface | 
| Interface algorithms | | Interface algorithms from existing packages |
| Data simulators | #353 | Add data simulators for unit testing and algorithm explanation/interpretability | 

## Supervised/Panel Forecasting
| Project | Links | Description | 
|---|---|---|
| API design | #66 | Design supervised forecasting API based on pysf | 

## Time Series Annotation
| Project | Links | Description | 
|---|---|---|
| API design | #260 | Design time series annotation API | 

## Data Container
| Project | Links | Description | 
|---|---|---|
| API design | #15 | Design data container interface | 
| Implementation | | Implement data container interface | 

## Development operations 
| Project | Links | Description | 
|---|---|---|
| CI | #196 | Improve continuous integration and development operations |

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at
the extension guidelines: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
Work on #212 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->
Refactors Time Series Forest Classifier to Regressor and creates a hierarchical structure for Forest-based estimators
#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is
necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value
all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to
review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering,
convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either
case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.

Thanks for contributing!
-->

issue.title: Refactor TSF classifier into TSF regressor

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
Working on issue #212. Following through with discussion with Ori and Marcus from this Monday, February 18th. 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Mostly focusing on translating TimeSeriesForest classifier into a regressor.

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
Not yet.

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?
Incremental code improvements.

#### Any other comments?
None yet.

#### PR checklist

##### For all contributions
- [x] (Luis) I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] (Kavin) I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/.all-contributorsrc).

##### For ~~new estimators~~ existing estimators:
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.
- [ ] *I've updated tests to ensure the API works.*

issue.title: [ENH] adapting ROCKETClassifier to ROCKETRegressor

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
Contributes to #212



#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Refactor ROCKETClassifier to ROCKETRegressor

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
No.
<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
-->

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->

body: Can you include the window size in ComposableTimeSeriesForestRegressor as well? So we can predict for few days ahead for multivariate time series.  Thank you.
@shuyanmei which window size do you mean? It's a regressor, not a forecaster. For temporal forward predictions, you should use `make_reduction` from `sktime.forecasting.compose`

@mloning , thank you for the reply. I think make_reduction is the one I am looking for. Another question is that I am trying to use lightgbm with sktime to predict a few days ahead with multiple features (include categorical features). Lightgbm in scikit-learn package can deal with categorical features directly as string format in 'fit' function without the need of encoding first. Since sktime is using scikit-learn's lightgbm, but seems that this function is not supported. If I understand correctly, based on https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/sktime/forecasting/compose/_reduce.py, it stacks the X, y data together and assign it to a initialized numpy ndarray first, and then fit to model. But 'string' can not be saved into numpy array, hence it caused the problem. I also didn't find tutorial on how to predict n-days ahead for multivariate data including categorical feature on the documentation. Since it is a very common scenario in reality, I am wondering is it supported so far and it is still underdevelopment?
I think that's right, currently the reduction approach only handles type-homogenous data due to the use of numpy arrays. A quick fix may be to encode the categorical data first.
the less quick but better fix is joining the `sktime` dev days next week and contribute to the refactoring forecasting and introducing multivariate functionality :smiley:

> the less quick but better fix is joining the `sktime` dev days next week and contribute to the refactoring forecasting and introducing multivariate functionality 

Just registered for the dev days and I am looking forward to it
